title: I was an Italian Master Chef üáÆüáπ
description:
‚ñ† ITALY, FLORENCE: The most challenging meal I've indulged in thus far in Florence, wasn't the 1.6 kg T-bone steak but Lisa's Lampredotto. It's not that the sandwich wasn't good. It really was quite tasty! 

It was more about having the knowledge of what I was eating and somehow muster the willpower to keep munching down on it despite my better judgement. 

Having seen my Lampredotto video, Martina, Florence's greatest tour guide, challenged me to sample some even more exotic ancient meals of Florence. So down to the 130 year old street food market known locally as Mercato di San Lorenzo I went. 

Objective: devour the most daring meals the city has got to offer. But first I was lured into taking the job as an Italian street food master chef! My first order, Panino con l'arrosto (whatever that is).

‚ñ† MARTINA'S CONTACT DETAILS: If you wish to join Martina on a food or history excursion you can write her at http://www.sunflorencetours.it/ her e-mail address is in the top left corner

title: Lost Inca City: Ollantaytambo Peru  üáµüá™
description:
‚ñ† PERU, SACRED VALLEY: Ollantaytambo was an important gateway city to Machu Picchu even 600 years ago. Today tourists pass through this town either by rail or road to the world famous Inca ruins. But this city have some pretty impressive ruins dating back to the heyday of the Inca empire as well.

Due to her strategic significance the city contained a fort which along with some agricultural terraces can be seen up close even today. Naturally this was something I had to investigate.

title: Amsterdam Wooden Shoes Race üá≥üá±
description:
‚ñ† MARKEN, NETHERLANDS: Last week I went shopping for traditional Dutch wooden shoes. Whilst there I also asked if they sold wooden socks. The answer was obviously no, but a few days after my visit to the Klompen museum, I got a message from Agent 47, the wood carving artist who sold me my shoes. He said he was working on a pair of wooden socks and that the prototype would be ready any day now.

Elated at the prospect of getting my feet on the world's first ever pair of wooden socks, I travelled back to the village of Marken with my Federal Reserves locked and loaded lest I lose out in a bidding-war for these collector's edition authentic Dutch wooden socks! 

 ‚ñ† How Wooden Shoes Are Made in Netherlands and my first video from the Klompenmakerij of Marken üá≥üá± https://youtu.be/6mJUWphCSMY

‚ñ† You can travel to see the world's first (and possibly most expensive) pair of wooden socks on the island of Marken, a 20 minutte Uber ride away from downtown Amsterdam.  They are on display at the Klompenmakerij Museum and Shop along with their 100 year old steam engine from Germany.

title: The Venice Experience: How Venetians Built an Empire üáÆüáπ
description:
‚ñ† ITALY, VENICE: The rags to ultra riches story of The Venetian Republic is unlike any other in European history. Refugees from the Roman Empire, fleeing the turmoil created by the power vacuum of Rome's waning ability to fend off endless barbarian incursions, turned a bunch of uninhabitable islands into the greatest and richest nation and finally empire in all of Europe.

How did the Venetians do it?

That is what I will explore as I take in what Venice, which is today just a city in Italy, has become in 2024. Venice is now a haven for tourists where one can truly take in what renaissance Italy was truly about.

The classic Venetian carnival still exists along with local artisans making traditional masks from scratch. Murano's glassmaking tradition also continues, possibly stronger than ever. 

La Serenissima lives on!

So tag along as I investigate the history of Venice from the year A.D. 500 all the way up to 2024 ‚õµÔ∏è

title: Sri Lanka Sea Turtle Savior üá±üá∞
description:
‚ñ† SRI LANKA, GALLE: Looking for things to do on the outskirts of town in Google Maps, I came across a Sea Turtle sanctuary operation. A family, with the help of volunteers and donations, have set up Sea turtle shelter on the beach where they nurse injured sea turtles back to health as well as rescue newly laid eggs from the dangers that lurch on the beach.

They dig-up and collect thousands of eggs and re-bury them within a fenced area, nursing them until they hatch. Then they set them free back in the ocean. They also help sea turtles damaged by fishing nets and propellers heal from their injuries (when possible).

Join me as I tour their facilities north of Galle city on Sri Lanka's southern coastline and get a fascinating look into this incredible operation.

title: Copa Libertadores Final Sucked! üáµüá™
description:
‚ñ† PERU, CUSCO: Having been to Brazil during the World Cup in 2014 and thus knowing that football in this part of the world mean one hell of a party outside the stadium before the game, hopes were sky high as I broke into my Federal Reserves to secure myself a ticket for the Copa Libertadores final in Lima Between Argentina's River Plate and Brazil's Flamengo. This was essentially like a national team match between Brazil vs. Argentina seeing a Peru's capital was full of people who'd flown in to support their team from two said nations.

There was only one problem. I had to go an pick up the ticket at a designated area before I could make my way to the match. And this little footnote , plus the organizers misinformation about what personal items were allowed into the stadium, pretty much ruined the whole Copa Libertadores final experience for me...

title: Don't Eat That in Peru üáµüá™
description:
‚ñ† PERU, SACRED VALLEY: The second last thing I expected to see driving through Peru's Sacred Valley were markets selling sweaters and other local products popular amongst tourists. But seeing as I did come across two, I decided to stop at them both and see what good they were peddling. 

At the second market, I came across a group of women who at first weren't overly eager to interact with me, but after a minute insinuated that the nuts they were cutting was for human consumption. So I decided to give them a go....

title: Machu Picchu Hike: Incas Under Spanish Rule  üáµüá™
description:
‚ñ† MACHU PICCHU, PERU: When the Spanish Conquistadores, with the backing of the Holy Roman Emperor Charles V's imperial ambitions, ventured deep into the Andes mountains of modern day Peru, they ran into another imperial power; the Incas.

From a little tribe on the brink of extinction in their home territory Cusco just 90 years earlier, they'd struck back and carved out a massive territory for themselves and in the process subdued all opposing tribes in what is today Bolivia, Peru, Ecuador, Chile and even parts of Argentina.

Exactly how less than 200 Spaniards managed to subjugate the powerful Incas, that's a topic I cover in a separate video. I'm having some technical issues with a corrupted file though, so exactly when I'll be able to upload it is anyone's guess at the moment. So to not keep you all waiting I'm uploading this one first. 

So who were the Incas? What was their society like? How did they fare under Spanish rule? I cover these and many other questions as I wander around what is to date the most unique world heritage site I've ever visited in person: Machu Picchu.

title: Superb Hike Inca Ruins Pisac üáµüá™
description:
‚ñ† PERU, PISAC: Whilst no mountain filled with historical ruins I've ever encountered could rival the sheer aesthetic beauty of Machu Picchu, said site does come with two major drawbacks:

1. There will be thousands of other people there during YOUR visit which somewhat puts a dampener on your ability to enjoy the site
2. Huge parts of it are off bounds to tourists which puts a mega dampener on your ability to enjoy the Inca ruins. 

At the Inca ruins of Pisac, which for the record encompasses a site which is 4 times larger than Macchu Picchu, you will not encounter any of these issues. I was the only one there for the first 2 hours of my hike.

But the main advantage of Pisac's Inca Ruins is that the hike itself is more scenic and interesting that any hike you can do on your day visit to Macchu Picchu. 

Don't believe me? Well, let me hear what you think after having seen the superb hiking trails I traversed up this morning starting at 05:55 AM at Pisac central market.

description:

There are large boat that fits 100 people or more per journey. And then there is Ambolux, the family run company where YOU can be the only passenger with your own private captain if you so wish. Here is the full video of my luxury boat your of the Amsterdam canals.

‚ñ† There are many canal boat tours advertised around Amsterdam, but when I asked my hotel for the one they'd recommend for the ultimate in luxury and service, they came back with Ambolux. It's a family run company which has been going for 5 years. The manager at my hotel told me a lot of the boat tour operators approach the hotel asking to cooperate. 

Having thus tried several different ones herself, so she could in good conscience recommend one to her hotel guests, she concluded that Ambolux was the best. 

‚ñ† Website: www.ambolux.com

title: Hunting Wild Burgers in Whopper Canyon üá∫üá∏
description:
‚ñ† ARIZONA, WHOPPER CANYON: Burger King's Double Whopper with bacon and cheese has long been the gold standard hamburger of the American fast food industry. Ever since I had my first Whopper, when Burger King opened their first restaurant near me back in 1996, I've been hooked. 

1000+ Burger King visits later and I thought I knew everything there was to know about the taste, price and nutritional value of the mighty whopper. . . 

. . . turns out, I was wrong! For apparently the juicy delicious double whopper didn't originally hail from anyone's kitchen. Instead, it traces its origins from the scorching hot desert in Arizona's Whopper Valley, which the mighty double whopper still migrates to from all over America to grill in the scorching desert heat every summer. 

Sounds far fetched? That's what I thought! So off I went with seasoned Double Whopper Hunter, Louise the Based Redcoat Brit, for an epic episode of Harald Investigates the secretive origins of Burger King's greatest hamburger: the mighty double whopper with bacon and cheese üçî

title: Knights Hospitaller Island: Medieval Rhodos üá¨üá∑
description:
‚ñ† RHODES, GREECE: As one of history‚Äôs most contested and thus fought over islands, Rhodes, which today is part of Greece, is one of Europe‚Äôs hidden gems if travelling to historic places is your forte. It is still a well known holiday destination but this incredible island doesn‚Äôt get the same publicity as Europe‚Äôs other tourism heavyweights.

So since I am in Rhodes for the second summer in a row, I figured I‚Äôd do my bit in changing just that. 

Ancient Rhodes was host to one of the earliest advanced civilisations of the Mediterranean prior to the Bronze Age collapse. A millennia later it was responsible for one of the 8 wonders of the ancient world: the colossus of Rhodes which guided ships safely into its famed harbour. 

Minoans, Dorians, Persians, Athenians, Romans, Byzantines, Ottomans, Italians and now Greeks finally again have all ruled this island.

I skipped over one of the most prominent and famed conquerors though. It was not a kingdom, empire, nation or even an ethnic group with a single language.

Instead it was a military crusading order which started out as a hospital run by traders from the Italian city state of Amalfi in what was then known as the Kingdom of Jerusalem in the year 1100 A.D. 

Today they are known to us as: The Knights Hospitaller or The Order of Saint John the Baptist

These bellicose monks who had picked up the sword to defend Christ and his worldly domains conquered Rhodes from the Byzantines in 1309 and ran the island for the benefit of what they called the one true faith, as their own country, for the next 213 years.

Not beholden to any nation, King or Emperor and only (nominally at least) recognising the Pope as an authority figure other than their own Grandmaster, these Knights soon became Europe and Christendom‚Äôs easternmost outpost in an increasingly Ottoman corner of the Mediterranean Sea. 

This video will cover some of the fascinating historical trivia surrounding this period the Knights Hospitaller ran this island as I visit one of Rhodos' oldest goldsmiths and they show us how to make a custom piece of jewelry from scratch using an ancient Rhodian method.

In between medieval history lessons and visits to the goldsmith for updates on my custom Knights Hospitaller ring order I will also wander about Rhodos Medieval old town and show you what makes Rhodes such an awesome place to holiday in from food, to shopping, beaches and hotels ‚öîÔ∏è

title: I hiked a castle in Pyrenees at night üá´üá∑
description:
‚ñ† PYRENEES, FRANCE: After driving the length of Italy and the French riviera in just 36 hours I arrived in my favorite region of France; the Pyrenees. This was the site of the Albigensian Crusades there the Catholic church in cahoots with the French king sought to subdue or slaughter the Cathars. The Cathars were a christian sect whom the pope viewed as heretical, quite possibly due to there refusal to pay tithe, or a tenth of ones' earnings to the church. 

This whole region is littered with a ridiculously high number of epic hilltop castle ruins, many of whom were used by the Cathars to hide from the onslaught of the Frankish crusaders. 

The biggest of all these structures still standing today is the Castle Peyrepertuse. To get to the castle itself one must first drive up half a mountain, then treck through a forest and up towards the top of the peak. 

Sounds easy right? Well how about doing all this in utter darkness before the sun is up. Did I succeed? This and more in my night siege of Castle Peyrepertuse.

Music used from Italian Composer Mattia Cupelli

Mattia Cupelli - Dark Choir Music
https://youtu.be/-GuD1rs9Z5I
